Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for the 19th Quantum Information Processing Workshop (QIP 2017)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 20th Quantum Information Processing Workshop (QIP 2017) will be held at the Westin Hotel in downtown Seattle, on 14-20 January 2017. QIP is the premier annual conference in the field, and is expected to bring together over 400 of the leading researchers in theoretical aspects of quantum information and computation.
QIP seeks to increase student participation in the field. It is proposed to offer approximately 20 US-based students and postdoctoral fellows NSF-sponsored travel grants to attend the conference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
QIP (for Quantum Information Processing) is an annual conference on quantum computation and information, usually held in January. Its goal is to represent the preceding year's best research in the area, in the form of both invited and contributed talks.

In 2017 the conference took place in Seattle, Washington. The goal of this travel grant was to allow U.S. graduate students to attend the conference by partially supporting their travel and housing costs. Participation by students and young emembers of the comunity in a major conference such as QIP is extremely important in developing their career, as it enables them to present their own research, learn about new developments in the field, and interact with more senior researchers. 

The travel grant consisted of $10,000. This amount was distributed among 20 successful applicants selected among a pool of 61 applicants in total, according to the criteria outlined in the proposal (in summary, scientific merit, representation of minorities, geographic representation). Among the 20 awards, two were made to exceptionally talented undergraduate students, and the remaining to graduate students. 3 of the awards were made to female applicants: this is a low number due to the unfortunately very limited number of female applicants, even though all efforts were made to publicize the award (as can be seen from the very high number of applicants, a ~40% increase compared to last year). The awards were made to applicants coming from 11 different US institutions. All awardees presented original research, either in the form of a contributed talk or a poster at the conference.
